channel.title: City of Playford - Latest - Google News

item.title: Playford Council chief executive Mal Hemmerling sacked after sexual harassment allegations - ABC News
item.description:
Playford Council chief executive Mal Hemmerling sacked after sexual harassment allegations  ABC News

An Adelaide council sacks its chief executive after an investigation into claims of repeated sexual harassment of staff. He plans to sue for defamation.

item.title: Former Playford Council mayor Marilyn Baker becomes deputy mayor as Mal Hemmerling dispute continues - The Advertiser
item.description:
Former Playford Council mayor Marilyn Baker becomes deputy mayor as Mal Hemmerling dispute continues  The Advertiser

Veteran councillor Marilyn Baker has successfully made a bid to become Playford Councils deputy mayor as it continues to grapple with the suspension of ...

item.title: Playford Council CEO Mal Hemmerling was stood down after secret review uncovered ‘culture of bullying’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
Playford Council CEO Mal Hemmerling was stood down after secret review uncovered ‘culture of bullying’  The Advertiser

Tensions within an embattled Adelaide councils senior ranks led to a secret review of manager conduct uncovering a culture of bullying, leaked correspondence ...

item.title: Claims Playford council boss was suspended over bullying claims after an internal “coup” plot - The Advertiser
item.description:
Claims Playford council boss was suspended over bullying claims after an internal “coup” plot  The Advertiser

The states highest paid council boss was suspended over bullying claims after an internal coup plot, it is claimed, as the local authority brings in a fourth law firm ...

item.title: Opposition says feud between Playford Council and suspended CEO must be resolved quickly - The Advertiser
item.description:
Opposition says feud between Playford Council and suspended CEO must be resolved quickly  The Advertiser

A feud between the states highest-paid council boss and his employer must be resolved quickly for ratepayers sake, says the State Opposition.

item.title: Acting council CEO accused of serious bullying - The Advertiser
item.description:
Acting council CEO accused of serious bullying  The Advertiser

The Sunday Mail has learned temporary Playford Council chief executive Sam Green, 42, was last week formally accused of serious bullying, shortly after being promoted. But Mr Green – who as deputy chief executive earned $273,270 with a ratepayer-funded car – remains at work despite his former boss, Mal Hemmerling, being suspended last month over similar allegations. Dr Hemmerling, 72, was sent home to Stirling on full pay from his $366,287-a-year chief executive role almost a month ago over claims of serious and wilful misconduct. Playford Council Mayor Glenn Docherty communicated the suspe...

item.title: Rubbish tossers leaving huge clean-up bill - The Advertiser
item.description:
Rubbish tossers leaving huge clean-up bill  The Advertiser

A SURGE in illegal rubbish dumping is leaving a trail of debris across the northern suburbs — and a huge clean-up bill for councils. Playford Council recorded 6640 cases of illegal dumping last financial year, up by 17 per cent on the previous year’s figure of 5529. While the figures are lower in Salisbury, the amount of recorded cases have nearly doubled in the same time frame, from 250 to 419. To combat the growing problem, Playford Council has increased its use of portable security cameras. Since deploying the CCTV cameras in May, which are being fitted temporarily to trees and signs, th...

item.title: $20m health precinct for northern suburbs - The Advertiser
item.description:
$20m health precinct for northern suburbs  The Advertiser

The five-storey health practice – which is expected to create about 150 fulltime health jobs – was given the green light by the council at its meeting on Tuesday night. GPaxis Munno Para medical centre owner Dr Jim Kosmas made the application to council to build the Playford Medical Hub, which is likely to be built at the new Prince George Plaza, in the Elizabeth business district. Following the meeting, Playford Council Mayor Glenn Docherty said: “Council has approved to sell allotment five to the developer. “Council is pleased that there are private investors willing to purchase in our (E...

item.title: Who can afford a rate rise of 300 per cent? - The Advertiser
item.description:
Who can afford a rate rise of 300 per cent?  The Advertiser

Growers, producers and workers waited up to six hours last night to address the council about its proposed rate rise for primary producers, which would see farms worth more than $1 million slugged with rates rises of double or triple. AUSVEG SA state manager Jordan Brooke-Barnett, who spoke at the meeting, said primary producers were just finding their feet after floods ravaged properties last year. “If you actually look at profitability a lot of the producers in the region are doing it tough,” Mr Brooke-Barnett said. “I have had growers come up to me saying that it is going to cost them be...

item.title: Gang’s all here to put talent on show - The Advertiser
item.description:
Gang’s all here to put talent on show  The Advertiser

More than 50 years later, the Comedy Capers Gang Show is still providing the laughs. The group was formed in 1965 by Ron Barnes as a way to bring together Scouts of all ages from across the northern suburbs. Comedy Capers organiser Bec Schoff, who has been involved for the past 13 years, said it is a great way for children and young people to build confidence. “A lot of the kids aren’t necessarily as accepted as much at school … so it really helps them to come out of their shells,” Ms Schoff, 25, of Salisbury Plain, says. More than 100 people aged 8-27 from across the north will help the co...

item.title: 5200 reasons for Adelaide to hang its head in shame - The Advertiser
item.description:
5200 reasons for Adelaide to hang its head in shame  The Advertiser

ABOUT 5200 cases of illegally dumped litter have been reported to northern councils so far this financial year — prompting local mayors to urge residents to clean up their act. From July to March, Playford Council recorded 4941 instances of illegal dumping in reserves, parks and streets across its district, while Salisbury Council tallied 241 cases. Playford’s figure compared to 5529 cases in 2015-16 and Salisbury’s compared to 250. It included general waste, cigarette butts, broken glass, liquid and domestic rubbish, and even hazardous waste such as asbestos. In March the Southern Times Me...

item.title: SA connection for hi-tech kiosks - The Advertiser
item.description:
SA connection for hi-tech kiosks  The Advertiser

Brisbane security company Sylo has developed technology that could potentially replace public phones with a single point of presence, combining more than 20 public services including phone, payment system to top up public travel and library cards, streaming news service and air and traffic monitoring and public information. Company chief executive Mark Hartmann - who is showcasing the Cortex technology at the Telstra Smart Communities Conference today and tomorrow - said he wanted to manufacture the units in Adelaide. “SA has a lot of incentives for us to do so,” he said, adding that Playfo...

item.title: Two multi-million dollar religious temples for the suburbs - The Advertiser
item.description:
Two multi-million dollar religious temples for the suburbs  The Advertiser

MULTI-MILLION dollar centres of worship are being planned by two northern religious groups – to meet the demands of the faithful. Applications by South Australia’s Shirdi Sai Baba community and the Peniel Free Pentecostal Church have been opened for public feedback by Playford Council. The Shirdi Sai Baba proposal is for a $2.2 million temple on Supple Rd, Waterloo Corner to accommodate its 100 members. The group, which established itself in the region in 2006, wants to host weekly prayer sessions. Their spiritual leader – the Indian saint Shirdi Sae Baba – is worshipped by a range of relig...

item.title: Pro tennis to Elizabeth - The Advertiser
item.description:
Pro tennis to Elizabeth  The Advertiser

The Playford Tennis International, played at the new Playford City Tennis Centre in Elizabeth, will run a second-tier $97,000 men’s event and entry level professional $32,000 ITF women’s event from December 30-January 7 next summer. It is a boost to tennis in SA, which lost the Adelaide International event to Brisbane in 2009, although it will not draw the top echelon of players that the former Memorial Drive event did. But it will attract players preparing for the Australian Open. Australian great Todd Woodbridge, who won the Adelaide International singles title in 1997, said Tennis Austra...

item.title: Water park to reopen but not in time to beat the heat - The Advertiser
item.description:
Water park to reopen but not in time to beat the heat  The Advertiser

A WATER park in Adelaide’s north is set to reopen by the end of the month - but not before local families have complained of being hot and bothered by the delay. In December, Playford Council closed its water play area at Playford Alive Town Park for maintenance and to meet new health and safety requirements. The delay in reopening has left families heated. One resident used the council’s Facebook page to label it “useless” and a “joke”. Another resident, who was responding to a post by the council that the park would reopen soon, said it was “bit late, summers (sic) pretty much over”, whil...

item.title: Adelaide road to be closed off so runway can be longer - The Advertiser
item.description:
Adelaide road to be closed off so runway can be longer  The Advertiser

A PORTION of a Penfield road will be closed to make way for the extension of a runway at the RAAF Base Edinburgh so a new fleet of bigger planes can land at the site. The Defence Department has bought an unused, unsealed section of Argent Rd from Playford Council, which will be used to extend its existing runway further north by about 275m. It will be used by the 12-strong Boeing P-8A Poseidon aircraft fleet, which took up residence at the base last year. A Defence spokesman said the Poseidons were about 2m longer than the AP-3C Orions that the aircraft has replaced, and the wingspan was 7m...

item.title: The SA water fountain that’ll be fit for a queen - The Advertiser
item.description:
The SA water fountain that’ll be fit for a queen  The Advertiser

Playford Council has released fresh artist impressions of the Fire and Water Fountain, which will be placed near the entry to the council’s $400 million Northern CBD development. The images show the fountain in a shallow pool and surrounded by squirting water features. It will be placed in the Prince George Plaza, which is named in honour of the Queen’s great-grandson. Mayor Glenn Docherty said the fountain was a key component of his council’s cultural history. “I believe this is an iconic piece of our history and I look forward to seeing it placed in the new Prince George Plaza,” Mr Docher...

item.title: Backflip a win for northern growers - The Advertiser
item.description:
Backflip a win for northern growers  The Advertiser

Playford councillors last week unanimously voted to axe a controversial plan to slug struggling farmers with a collective $1.8 million rate rise in 2017/18. Farmers – many still recovering from last year’s floods – have applauded the council’s decision to keep the status quo, saying they can finally get back to business. GTS Farms owner Ross Trimboli is one of 1700 residents who made a submission to the council opposing the planned changes, claiming it would hinder his potato farm at Virginia. “We made it very clear that we could not absorb these increasing council rates, for that very reas...

item.title: North’s new building boom on the rink of success - The Advertiser
item.description:
North’s new building boom on the rink of success  The Advertiser

The $35 million Playford Arena development, which has been endorsed by Playford Council and is awaiting State Cabinet approval in January, is likely to be the first major project at the new Prince George Plaza, in the Elizabeth business district. At a meeting on Tuesday night, Playford Council is also poised to approve an application to build a health practice at the same site. The plan, by GPaxis Munno Para medical centre owner Dr Jim Kosmas, is understood to be worth up to $20 million. Mayor Glenn Docherty said the council had been working hard to bring private investment and new jobs to ...

item.title: Editorial, August 13: Housing must be affordable for young - The Advertiser
item.description:
Editorial, August 13: Housing must be affordable for young  The Advertiser

The state’s longest-serving premier, Sir Thomas Playford, nationalised the electricity system, creating ETSA in 1946, determined to fuel low-cost power with Leigh Creek coal. Then Playford drove the construction of thousands of low-cost homes for workers to fill the burgeoning factory base, through the South Australian Housing Trust, created in 1936. Playford’s reign, which ended in 1965, is a distant memory. Unfortunately, the days of low-cost electricity are long gone. Now, Master Builders South Australia is arguing the state’s longstanding reputation as having some of the nation’s most a...

item.title: Plans for new Ice Arena on thin ice - The Advertiser
item.description:
Plans for new Ice Arena on thin ice  The Advertiser

THE future of a $50 million ice arena in the north remains unclear, with the State Government tight lipped on whether it will help fund the centre. Ice Rinks Adelaide director Stephen Campbell has delayed the opening date of Playford Arena as he waits on financial assistance from the State Government. Mr Campbell has asked the State Government for a loan to partially fund the arena — which he says is a “very small” portion of the overall cost — planned for the corner of Main North Rd and Philip Highway. But he has not heard back whether the funds will be available to help get work started o...

item.title: Councillor charged with aggravated assault - The Advertiser
item.description:
Councillor charged with aggravated assault  The Advertiser

Court documents, obtained by the Northern Weekly, show Playford councillor Michael Joy, 32, of Elizabeth Grove, was arrested following an incident on July 19 in Magill involving his estranged wife. Cr Joy was charged with aggravated assault and appeared in the Adelaide Magistrates Court on August 17. He did not enter a plea and the case was deferred to October 26. Cr Joy declined to comment when contacted by the Northern Weekly last week. A Playford Council spokesman also declined to comment while the matter was before the courts. Cr Joy was elected in 2010 as a representative of Ward Five,...

item.title: Elizabeth Vale eyes new health hub - The Advertiser
item.description:
Elizabeth Vale eyes new health hub  The Advertiser

South Australia’s not-for-profit ACH Group is behind a plan to convert a 22,500sqm site adjacent the flagship Lyell McEwin hospital in Elizabeth Vale into a major development boasting myriad health services, education, training and social housing. ACH chairman Geoff Holdich said the site master plan will be submitted to the City of Playford in January next year with construction on the restorative health and wellbeing project, due to begin in the second half of 2017, taking five years to complete. “This project will definitely take place, it’s exciting and we are expecting a positive respon...

item.title: Flood-proof plan needs funds - The Advertiser
item.description:
Flood-proof plan needs funds  The Advertiser

South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill has written to Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull requesting his government match $9 million in funding for a series of levees and upgrades along the Gawler River. The aim is to prevent a repeat of last year’s flood which affected 250 growers, destroyed 750 greenhouses and caused more than $50 million in crop damage. Gawler River Floodplain Management Authority, which is made up of the Playford, Adelaide Plains, Light Regional, Barossa, Gawler and Adelaide Hills councils, would fund the remaining $9 million. The $27 million investment is expected to prot...

item.title: First fine under new illegal dumping laws - The Advertiser
item.description:
First fine under new illegal dumping laws  The Advertiser

A NORTHERN suburbs man has become the first person in the state to be convicted under new anti-dumping laws. Ahmad Rafique, of Elizabeth Downs, was convicted this month of illegal dumping by the Environmental, Resources and Development Court. In March, Rafique emptied two wheelie bins filled with green waste, plastic bags, bottles and household waste on Argana Park — which is owned and managed by Playford Council. Witnesses at the oval reported the incident to the council. Rafique was fined $1000 under the Local Nuisance and Litter Control Act 2016, which came into effect in July. After he ...

item.title: Editorial: Triple-A rating stays but turbulent times ahead - The Advertiser
item.description:
Editorial: Triple-A rating stays but turbulent times ahead  The Advertiser

Shortly after Treasurer Scott Morrison delivered his midyear budget update yesterday, the big three financial ratings agencies reaffirmed the nation’s credit rating. But, in doing so, they sent pessimistic messages about the government’s willingness and ability to find budget savings or revenue measures to cut deficits. Put simply, the nation continues to live beyond its means and the financial experts do not have great confidence in the Government’s commitment to return the Budget to surplus by 2020-21. Continuing Budget deficits and unsustainable spending leaves Australia exposed – albeit...

item.title: The Adelaide schools putting students on payrolls - The Advertiser
item.description:
The Adelaide schools putting students on payrolls  The Advertiser

Between them, Playford International College at Elizabeth and Wirreanda Secondary at Morphett Vale plan to formally employ about 150 students next year, in a bid to introduce students in struggling parts of the city to the world of employment. Students will also be able pitch ideas about other jobs they believe need doing around campus, and apply for grants or scholarships to launch their own school-based businesses. At Playford, the move is part of a wide-ranging transformation that will also see traditional recess and lunch breaks scrapped, while the school bell will ring no more. Princip...

item.title: Six-storey carpark approved for Elizabeth - The Advertiser
item.description:
Six-storey carpark approved for Elizabeth  The Advertiser

Playford Council’s development assessment panel has approved the multi-level building’s construction – at the corner of Main North Rd and Philip Highway, Elizabeth. It will hold 360 vehicles, servicing Playford CBD, which is currently under construction and includes Prince George Plaza and Playford Medical Hub. A developer has long-held plans too for an ice arena, subject to government funding and approval. Playford Mayor Glenn Docherty welcomed the carpark decision. “The 360 parks over six storeys will provide even more parking access to our growing community and unlock our CBD precinct,” ...

item.title: One council’s plan for affordable living, job creation - The Advertiser
item.description:
One council’s plan for affordable living, job creation  The Advertiser

The council this month released a Rates Policy Review, which proposes $636,000 a year in residential rates relief, meaning slightly cheaper bills for two-thirds of homeowners. The big winners would be owners of commercial properties, who would collectively pay $2.5 million less in rates each year. But rather than reduce spending to deliver the cuts, the council would increase rates on vacant land and collect an extra $1.8 million from large-scale primary producers, many of whom are recovering from last year’s floods. A staff report revealed most businesses in Playford were paying more than ...

item.title: The Wedding Singer comes to Adelaide - The Advertiser
item.description:
The Wedding Singer comes to Adelaide  The Advertiser

Robbie Hart, played by year 10 student Liam Tomlin in a new production at the Shedley Theatre, is juggling a failed relationship with his fiance and a new love. The musical version of the 1998 film The Wedding Singer willhit the stage at Elizabeth tomorrow night, starring Roma Mitchell Secondary College students. “It’s been really interesting playing Robbie because we share a lot of similarities, but at the same time we have so many differences,” Liam says. “For example I’m a clean-cut person whereas Robbie is a bit of a slob and wakes up in the morning and puts on the same clothes he had o...

item.title: The 2016 council decisions we loved — and loathed - The Advertiser
item.description:
The 2016 council decisions we loved — and loathed  The Advertiser

Look for your local council below: ADELAIDE CITY Bouquet: In June, the council delivered some much-needed relief to ratepayers by deciding to freeze rates in 2016/17. The move has triggered council members to investigate further business options, including one day making Adelaide a rate-free city. Brickbat: After almost two years, the council is edging closer to fixing the problematic Frome St Bikeway. The council will this year rip up the separated bikeway, which was built at a cost of $1.6 million, returning Frome St to two lanes of traffic. The street will get a standard bike lane, but l...

item.title: ’They want us to pay for their inner-city lifestyles’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
’They want us to pay for their inner-city lifestyles’  The Advertiser

A gallery of around 300 primary producers erupted into applause this week as councillors voted not to change the way rates are distributed — a move that received about 1700 written submissions in the past three weeks. Cr Joe Federico said the council had made the mistake of assuming producers with highly-valued land could afford to pay more. “No one has a monopoly on hardship … We’re just shifting (costs) from one end of the spectrum to the other end,” he said. Cr Denis Davey conceded there was overwhelming public support not to change the rate distribution model despite his preference to c...

item.title: Angry citizens unite against council waste - The Advertiser
item.description:
Angry citizens unite against council waste  The Advertiser

Residents’ associations that have already agreed to campaign against shared problems across the sector include those from Onkaparinga, Playford and Salisbury council areas, the Adelaide Hills, Port Augusta and Murray Mallee. The Copper Coast Residents’ and Ratepayers’ Association was formed at a meeting at Moonta on Sunday, where 300 people from residents’ groups across SA formally joined forces to begin a statewide campaign. Copper Coast resident Andrew Skinner said Facebook would be used to bridge the geographical divide between the groups and co-ordinate activities. “We want all the rate...

item.title: Unveiling $1.4m road fix: 160 crashes in five years - The Advertiser
item.description:
Unveiling $1.4m road fix: 160 crashes in five years  The Advertiser

The work on a 900m section of Main North Rd at Blakeview, where there has been 160 crashes over a five-year period, has cost about $1.4m. The upgrade included adding new U-turn slots with deceleration lanes, extending the right-hand turning lane on to Craigmore Rd, upgrading median strips and adding new turning points. It was in response to government figures that showed 160 crashes had occurred at the site from 2011-2015 – of which, five were serious and 33 were minor crashes. The remaining 122 resulted in property damage only with no reported injuries. In August, a Lewiston man died after...

item.title: Police search for witnesses to Whyalla crash - The Advertiser
item.description:
Police search for witnesses to Whyalla crash  The Advertiser

Police are investigating the crash which occurred about 12.45am at the intersection of Nicolson Ave and Bradford St. The man behind the wheel was taken to Whyalla Hospital with minor injuries while both roads were closed for crews to repair damaged power lines. Anyone with information is encouraged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

item.title: Why this is not your average load of rubbish - The Advertiser
item.description:
Why this is not your average load of rubbish  The Advertiser

The bin sends a message to the collector when it’s full. It also has a compactor, powered by solar energy, that compacts waste every time it is placed in the bin. Smart City Solutions chief executive Luke Johnston said the bin helped council workers prioritise their time. “It means that council workers don’t have to visit the bins if they don’t need to and can put their time into other projects,” Mr Johnston said. “Councils are growing day-by-day so they are always looking for new projects and ways to improve their time management.” The bins cost from $4500 to $6500. They also can be used a...

item.title: Your guide to what’s on in Adelaide - The Advertiser
item.description:
Your guide to what’s on in Adelaide  The Advertiser

Friday, October 6 CITY Diabetes Australia Walk to Work Day Now in its 19th year, Walk to Work encourages employees and employers to build walking into their everyday lives. Walking to meetings, walking to and from work, taking a walk at lunchtime and using the stairs instead of the elevator are just some of the ways you can start. Participants also have the opportunity to help raise vital funds for Diabetes Australia. Various locations, times and prices. Details here Nature Play Festival Participate in this annual festival for children and their families, celebrating and encouraging outdoor...

item.title: Calling cafes, bars and restaurants: New plaza needs you - The Advertiser
item.description:
Calling cafes, bars and restaurants: New plaza needs you  The Advertiser

Playford Council is calling on existing eateries keen to expand or prospective business owners to register their interest for sites available at its new Prince George Plaza. Norwood-based Intrepid Property is handling the expressions of interest process. Managing director Craig Feely said the 305sq m space could be occupied by a sole business or divided into 40sq m spaces to accommodate four separate eateries. “We are looking for all kinds of food users,” Mr Feely said. “And I mean fresh food, takeaway foods and even dine-in (operators). “There is going to be a strong focus on South Austral...

item.title: Racist vandals desecrate Stolen Generation memorial - The Advertiser
item.description:
Racist vandals desecrate Stolen Generation memorial  The Advertiser

Christine Doolan, one of the women behind the Stolen Generation Memorial and Healing Garden in Stebonheath Park at Andrews Farm, told The Advertiser she was still in shock after noticing the trail of destruction this week. “They have smashed and pulled some of the tiles out, but have also scratched a big swastika into a plague,” Ms Doolan said. “It physically makes you feel sick that someone could do this. It is really upsetting for everyone in the community to see this, not just for Aboriginal people.” Ms Doolan, of Davoren Park, said she was struggling to comprehend why anyone would vanda...

item.title: Ultimate guide to 1160 Fringe acts - The Advertiser
item.description:
Ultimate guide to 1160 Fringe acts  The Advertiser

Real-life siblings Celeste Carbone and Deanna Kangas and bandmate Aaron Collis have made the radical conversion from performing in long-running children’s act The Funkees to create their own, adults-only cabaret show. “The market for kids’ stuff has changed a lot … we started creating this in our downtime,’’ Ms Kangas said. “One of the things that has worked for us is bringing the energy we have in children’s entertainment into the adult space.’’ Two Brunettes and a Gay, which will be in The Bally tent at Gluttony from February 17 to March 4, is among 1160 shows and events in the bumper, 14...

item.title: $1.8m roundabout to go where there’s been 12 crashes - The Advertiser
item.description:
$1.8m roundabout to go where there’s been 12 crashes  The Advertiser

AN intersection in Adelaide’s north that has long been a hotspot for crashes — and where more than a dozen people have been injured in the past decade — is finally to get a roundabout, that’ll cost $1.8m to install. The Craigmore intersection that has been the site of 12 crashes in the past decade is finally being addressed — and locals couldn’t be happier. The State Government will spend $1.8 million installing a roundabout at the Yorktown Rd and Blair Park Drive intersection next month in a bid to improve safety for motorists. The works are due to begin next month and are expected to be c...

item.title: $50,000 damage and counting: How to stop corellas? - The Advertiser
item.description:
$50,000 damage and counting: How to stop corellas?  The Advertiser

CHIEFS at Playford Council are considering using an eagle to scare away corellas wreaking havoc on its buildings, playgrounds, street lights and even a golf course. Thousands of the birds have flocked from the Far North to areas in Munno Para, Smithfield Plains and Craigmore in the past two months. Playford Council estimates the birds have caused about $50,000 worth of damage during that time, including chewing electrical wires and street light covers along Curtis Rd, Munno Para. Shade sails at the Playford Alive Town Park have also been torn, trees across the region are missing bark and le...

item.title: SA council’s China footy junket - The Advertiser
item.description:
SA council’s China footy junket  The Advertiser

Playford Council was forced to release documents detailing the cost of Mayor Glenn Docherty’s 10-day trip to China in May after an application under the Freedom of Information Act. Tickets to the Port v Suns AFL game were not paid for by ratepayers but they will have to fork out $15,281.74 for other costs — including $1800 for a “travel allowance”, $3,253 for accommodation, $4,393 for flights, $994 for meals, $938 for “miscellaneous” items and $1,190 for tickets to a gala dinner. A similar trip was taken by Onkaparinga Council, but neither council represents ratepayers in Port Adelaide’s AF...

item.title: School has nearly 300 student bans in one year - The Advertiser
item.description:
School has nearly 300 student bans in one year  The Advertiser

as parent surveys across multiple schools reveal behaviour management as a top concern. And many schools are failing to detail the scale of their behaviour problems, an Advertiser review of high school annual reports has found. The number of serious behaviour incidents at Playford International College rose from 250 to 288 in 2016, with more than 40 per cent related to violence. Other annual reports reveal: GOLDEN Grove High almost doubled the number of students suspended from 34 to 63, while referrals to a behaviour “focus room” rose from 182 to 233. BRIGHTON Secondary issued 83 suspension...

item.title: Popular northern suburb draws in bargain hunters - The Advertiser
item.description:
Popular northern suburb draws in bargain hunters  The Advertiser

According to CoreLogic data, the suburb which sits, about 22km from the CBD recorded the highest number of sales in the Salisbury and Playford council areas the past year. There were 280 houses sold in Paralowie in the 12 months to February, which took 49 days on average to be snapped up. The area has a median house price of $295,000, which is up from $277,000 at the same time last year but still cheaper than the wider Salisbury council’s area’s $322,000 median. Ray White Salisbury agent Andrew Farnworth said Paralowie’s affordable and family-friendly vibe was attractive to prospective home...

item.title: SA, home to biggest undercover lawn bowls complex? - The Advertiser
item.description:
SA, home to biggest undercover lawn bowls complex?  The Advertiser

AUSTRALIA’S largest undercover lawn bowls complex will be built in Elizabeth, under a plan to redevelop sports facilities in the north. Playford Council has released plans to build new clubrooms and install three undercover artificial pitches at Elizabeth Bowling Club on Goodman Rd. Under the plans, Elizabeth and Munno Para bowling clubs would merge and share the complex. The complex would be used by more than 180 members from the clubs. Elizabeth Bowling Club president Jim Main welcomed the announcement. “This new club will help rejuvenate Playford and provide a complex which is noticeable...

item.title: What’s next for our northern suburbs? - The Advertiser
item.description:
What’s next for our northern suburbs?  The Advertiser

The brothers learnt their trade as teenagers in their parents’ butcher’s shop in Dublin, before opening their own shop in Burton’s Springbank Plaza in 2010. Today, their company, D & S Meats, employs 30 people and has shops in Angle Vale, Blakes Crossing, Playford Alive, Munno Para, Mawson Lakes and Golden Grove. And they continue to have faith in region, and its people, with plans for an eighth shop in Gilles Plains. “We grew up in the north and we know the area and the people really well,” Danny says. “They are the most genuine people you can meet.” The car industry’s decline has coincide...

item.title: Mega undercover bowls complex finally open - The Advertiser
item.description:
Mega undercover bowls complex finally open  The Advertiser

At times, their dream of a mega bowls complex on Goodman Rd, Elizabeth, seemed out of reach. But when keys to the new centre finally landed in the hands of club president Jim Main, the reality hit them. “We went in and had a meeting with the Playford bowls board (on May 16) and all hugged each other, it was a bit emotional I tell you,” Mr Main, 84, of Gawler says. “The feeling was magnificent, it was like we had gone home.” The new $7 million complex, which is the largest undercover lawn bowls arena in the southern hemisphere, will be opened by Playford Mayor Glenn Docherty next Wednesday. ...

item.title: Councils trying to keep rate rise down - The Advertiser
item.description:
Councils trying to keep rate rise down  The Advertiser

A proposed increase of 3 per cent is up for community consultation for Playford City residents, who are facing an average price hike of $45 per household. Those living in Salisbury Council’s district may see a 2 per cent jump – an extra $24 next financial year. Playford’s proposal, outlined in the council’s 2018/19 Annual Business Plan and Budget, is 0.2 per cent higher than the rate rise for the current year of 2.8 per cent. The $45 increase equates to nearly 12.5 cents per day and is based on the average capital value of a home in the district, which is $238,000. Playford Mayor Glenn Doch...

item.title: 'Plague' of noisy corellas lay siege to Adelaide - ABC News
item.description:
'Plague' of noisy corellas lay siege to Adelaide  ABC News

Thousands of noisy corellas in search of food are terrorising residents in the northern suburbs of Adelaide, wreaking havoc to street lights, signs and trees. The local council has tried using everything from drones to pyrotechnics to disperse the birds, but now they are calling on the Environment Department to take charge. Imagine this noise three times a day A flock of corellas captured on a mobile phone flying over a house at Andrews Farm shows the level of noise the birds make as they pass over homes. External Link: Corellas terrorising SA suburb Sandy Bandtock said that scene and sound...

item.title: Huge mural pays tribute to 54 years of Holden - The Advertiser
item.description:
Huge mural pays tribute to 54 years of Holden  The Advertiser

Celebrated Brisbane artist Cam Scale — known for his murals on the Kimba silos — worked with former Holden employees to come up with a design to capture what Holden’s 54 years in the northern suburbs has meant to the region. “It’s an honour to create this mural and represent something that’s been a massive part of this city for so many years,” Mr Scale said. “It’s a large-scale mural of some collage images of different stages of the production line of Holden and wrapping in the different parts of the history.” The project gave Mr Scale the opportunity to mentor young emerging Adelaide artis...

item.title: Councils cancel Australia Day events due to extreme heat - The Advertiser
item.description:
Councils cancel Australia Day events due to extreme heat  The Advertiser

With temperatures expected to hit 39 in parts of the metropolitan area, councils have already begun to cancel and reschedule events, with some moved indoors, while others will have their elected members vote on whether to proceed. Other concerts and events are also expected to be affected. We will keep you posted on cancelled and rescheduled events in your area. NORTH Salisbury — cancelled Salisbury announced on Monday night that it has cancelled its planned family picnic at Carisbrooke Park. Playford — moved Playford Council has moved its Australia Day breakfast from Elizabeth’s Fremont Pa...

item.title: Our top citizens honoured on Australia Day - The Advertiser
item.description:
Our top citizens honoured on Australia Day  The Advertiser

ACROSS Adelaide, here at the winners of Australia Day citizens of the year. Burnside IT IS hard for Burnside’s citizen of the year Jill Ferris to see the difference she makes to girls’ lives as a ballet teacher at the Kathleen Short Ballet School. That is because she has been involved as a ballet student and then an instructor for 71 of her 78 years. It is not hard, though, for everyone else at the Toorak Gardens school to recognise Mrs Ferris’s impact. “She just graciously gives her time, all the time,” says Jenni Chew, a mother of three girls at the school. “She makes all the costumes, fi...

item.title: Look who’s coming to the northern suburbs for Fringe - The Advertiser
item.description:
Look who’s coming to the northern suburbs for Fringe  The Advertiser

Playford and Salisbury councils last week released some of the acts locked in at their respective festival venues — Playford Palace and the Secret Garden. Helliar has signed on as the Palace headline act. The Playford venue, which was launched this year, will expand from two days to three in 2018, to be held from February 23-25. Other entertainers are expected to be announced early next year. Playford Mayor Glenn Docherty was looking forward to growing the northern festival venue. “We want to continue to provide our community with the opportunity to experience the Adelaide Fringe closer to ...

item.title: Sing carols with Anthony Callea and Rachael Leahcar - The Advertiser
item.description:
Sing carols with Anthony Callea and Rachael Leahcar  The Advertiser

Playford Council expects more than 7000 people to sing along to favourites like Silent Night and Joy to the World this Saturday at its Playford Community Carols at Fremont Park. Australian Idol runner-up Anthony Callea and The Voice singer Rachael Leahcar are headlining the annual event, which includes local entertainers such as children’s band Cool 4 Kids and gospel choir Gospo Collective. Cool 4 Kids performer Tony Genovese says interacting with so many families is a highlight for the group. “We are looking forward to spreading the Christmas cheer and seeing all the smiles on the children...

item.title: Things go swimmingly at SAFCOL - The Advertiser
item.description:
Things go swimmingly at SAFCOL  The Advertiser

More than 30 jobs are expected to be created across the next 12 months through an expansion of SAFCOL’s production plant, with the company opening up new markets in the Middle East, Vietnam, Malaysia, New Zealand and China. SAFCOL, founded in 1945 by South Australian Fishermans Co-operative Limited, is one of the world’s major suppliers of fresh, packaged and frozen seafood. More than $10 million has been invested into the project, which includes building two new warehouses across 4000sq m. It will harness green energy too, with solar panels to power the site and allow the fish and food pro...
